Award.AwardTitle: Research Starter Grant: Understanding savanna vegetation dynamics in East Africa under different off-take methods and precipitation regimes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding savanna vegetation dynamics in East Africa under different off-take methods and precipitation regimes

Savanna vegetation comprises a large percentage of the total land surface area in East Africa and savannas are important for the sustainability of millions of livestock keeping pastoralists and wildlife. The ecological processes underlying the dynamics of savanna vegetation are the result of interactions between moisture, nutrients, fire and herbivory. The objective of this research is to rely on experimental field studies, which incorporate more real-world conditions, in order to better understand vegetation dynamics of savannas, specifically, how the method of vegetative off-take matters for regrowth. The investigation will utilize experimental treatments through enclosures across a precipitation gradient within the Serengeti-Mara Ecosystem of East Africa. This project will contribute new knowledge on how savannas might be impacted in future generations and addresses the implications of these changes for the sustainability of people, landscapes and wildlife.

This research will have a direct bearing on conservation and development policies, contributing to new knowledge and the development of policies which more fully consider the real world conditions affecting savannas. The project will enhance the participation of underrepresented groups by training local Maasai peoples in ecological monitoring and evaluation. The project will also benefit undergraduate students from the University of Michigan and the University of Nairobi who will be part of a yearly study abroad effort to understand the ecological dimensions of conservation and development strategies in East African savannas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent research on the dynamics of savanna vegetation has yet to more fully consider how the effects of grazing on forage quality differ in areas where the overlap between wildlife and livestock is growing, or how precipitation gradients and increased climatic variability are likely to affect these dynamics. The objective of this research is therefore to rely on experimental field studies, which incorporate more real-world conditions, in order to better understand vegetation dynamics of savannas. In order to achieve the objective, this research queried how the method of vegetative off-take matters for regrowth by relying on experimental treatments through enclosures across a precipitation gradient within the Serengeti-Mara Ecosystem of East Africa. These treatments include: grazing by domestic cattle only; grazing by wildlife only; grazing by both domestic cattle and wildlife; lightly burning vegetative cover;  artificial clipping of vegetative cover, and untreated vegetation. Three research questions are posed: (A) How do different off-take methods influence the structure and composition of savanna vegetation? (B) Are there significant differences in the nutritional composition of grasses under different off take scenarios? (C) How are these nutritional differences affected by precipitation gradients? 

The intellectual merit of the research finds that sites grazed by both wildlife and livestock maintain higher protein and energy content with harvested grasses than those that were ungrazed, burnt, or artifically clipped. This relationship is true across an increasing precipitation gradient, and across the course of seasonal calendar. Across wetter and drier sites, there were no statistically valid differences across any of the treatments, indicating that precipitation may not be as strong a factor in influencing vegetative growth. We found no significant differences between the protein content on grasses that had been grazed exclusively by wildlife versus livestock. There was a statistically significant difference between the forage quality of grasses that have been artifically clipped and those grasses left untreated, where grasses artifically clipped had higher level of protein and energy content that grasses left untreated.

Additionally, while building, constructing and planning the exclosures, we found little or no evidence for why exclosures are selected or maintained in particular ways, instead relying on statistical designs which do not accurately or representatively account for the lived realities of African pastoral ecosystems. 

The broader impacts of this research occur through a direct influence on conservation and development policies, which historically have been hampered by the lack of empirical evidence on how and under what conditions vegetation regrowth is influenced by the method of vegetative off-take and under differing precipitation conditions. This lack of information has contributed to policies which have had adverse effects on the sustainability of pastoralists and wildlife. This research sheds new light on conservation policies that encourage rather than discourage greater integration between wildlife and livestock.  The project enhanced the participation of underrepresented groups by training local Maasai peoples in ecological monitoring and evaluation, and by training several minority collaborators ranging from freshmen university students to first year graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher.
